								This game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly simple-minded and boring; that is my rating! It is not worth the $30.00 USD that it is being marketed for. Now what may I mean by that you ask; well allow me to explain.Blitzkrieg 3 is nothing like it's predecessors; the infamous Blitzkrieg and Blitzkrieg 2. Both of these games were traditional RTS with different twists in game mechanics and plot lines. Blitzkrieg 3 has no plot line, and is more in line with a crappy Warlords or Clash of Clans (yes....dare I speak that name) in the sense that your only goal is to either bash endless amounts of "player-owned bases" or engage in poorly designed "Historical" missions. It is not an RTS but is more like a Mobile App game that has been given the skin of Blitzkrieg. There is no Map for you to conquer, only 3 Factions to choose from (typical German, U.S, U.S.S.R), and you are only able to use the same 12 units (6 Inft. and 6 Armor) throughout the game; as well as a few "Support" abilities (like Mortars/Smoke). I say all of this because it's system seems more like App graphics than a professionally designed PC "AA" or "AAA" game. Indeed I'd dare say this systme runs very much like War Commander; the MMO-Base Builder game on Facebook. Thus, in this writers opinion, it is not worth the $30.00; let alone does it belong on PC (should be a IOS game IMHO).But you may ask what about the Gameplay, or the Graphics; for surely those must mean something with all those positive reviews. Allow me to explain from my first-hand experience. The Blitzkrieg series has always been more about large size battles and epic "on-map" destruction that leave the player feeling part of some epic war drama film. This, at least for this writer, is what made the past games so alluring. Burning wrecks, destroyed buildings, massive arty bombardments, and craters everywhere; all of these made Blitzkrieg a great game (and predecessor to todays total war-style games). Blitzkrieg 3 shows none of this, and in fact is a step back from it's traditional roots. Both the Graphics system and the Game Mechanics run more akin to Clash of Clans (yes....dare I speak that name again). Wrecks do not remain on the battlefield, gunfire is simple even on Ultra setting, maps are barely decent at best, the defense/offense systems are poorly balanced to the point of forcing a player to use mainly Armored units to succeed. While I could continue commenting on the poor Gameplay/Graphics I leave it to you to imagine your disappoint if you waste that $30.00.In this writers opinion there are only 2 good things to take away from this project. The first is the base defense system; which is decent at best. I did enjoy the fact that my map extended beyond my given base design, and that I could move my defense where ever I pleased on the map. That being this very same system is broken because the defensive weapons tend to out perform even the Lvl 6 Armor/Inft; thus making it hard to swipe anyone's base on your own lvl and up (I can see the Trolls enjoying this). The other good thing was the nice Tutorial, which was very helpful (minus the glitch on the Panzergrenedier Mission). That being said it seem too.....bland......for this writers tastes. Could this game become better, you may ask; worth it's $30.00 price tag. Sadly I'm afraid not, as many of my fellow gamers are slowly discovering. As I stated earlier this game is more akin to Clash of Clans, and not worth $30.00 (more like $10.00 at most). Even if the Devs added a map, fixed the Graphics quality, added more units, made more buildings, or even put a good plot line in place the game still have one problem. It's a Massive Multiplayer Online Base Building game.....something most gamers will only attribute with Mobile Apps and iPhones/Androids. It is nothing like it's predecessor, Blitzkrieg 1 + 2, and it angers this writer to know how far the Devs have taken this game out of it's normal setting. Finally, even if fully upgraded and sold, it is not worth $30.00 freak'in dollars. Anyway I hope this is both a helpful review of the Devs, as much as a friendly warning for my fellow gamers. Waste your money at your own risk, but your better off finding a good FB MMOBB like CoC, War Commander, or Martian Invader that are cheap or FREE (key word FREE here kiddies).

Early Access Review
								Below is my original review, unchanged from when I published it.  I wanted to write an update.  As of 6/27/2015, the devs are adding real PvP against real players.  While I admit in my review that it isn't my cup of tea, it was also why I felt some may not like this game.  The fact that they listened to those who wanted real PvP is awesome-sauce.  And I wanted to send a big kudos to the devs for continually making this game better.============================================The single player campaigns are similar to Blitzkrieg 2, albeit the RPG element of it is lacking in comparison to Blitzkrieg 2.The multiplayer campaign can be explained very simply.  It is Clash of Clans...world war 2 style.Before you say "Cool" or "No way!" (depending on how you feel about Clash of Clans).  There are some differences.The main difference is no waiting.  You don't spend "gems" or some equivalent resource which can only be obtained with real money.  You build your army, you go to battle and then you battle again and again and again.Your whole army gets wiped out?  No problem, they are immediately available for the next battle.  No waiting for buildings to finish, no waiting for troops to build.  If you can afford to build it, you get it immediately and it is always there.So, in my opinion, it has the allure Clash of Clans has minus the moneygrabbing nonsense clash of clans has.  If I want to play Blitzkrieg 3, I can play for as long as I wish.  I don't have to worry about troops or waiting, it is quite refreshing.The RPG element is similar to clash of clans.  You want that Panzer IV?  Well, you need to upgrade your tank depot...but before that, your HQ needs to upgrade.  In order to do that, you need 3000 fuel or 5000 supplies, etc.  The only way you get it is to raid other players.On the other side, your base is something you need to defend.  There seems to be a variety of maps players can start off with.  (You don't get to choose) and each map has 3 or 4 ways to infiltrate your base.  Your defenses are limited and you need to place them strategically.When you raid others, it is awesome when you hit someone who has the same map as you...then you can say, "Hey, why didn't I think of that?" and improve your own defenses.  My hours aren't that deep at the time of this review.  I can't comment too much on single player.  I've been having so much fun with  multiplayer.  It really is odd, because my library of games is single player only.This game stole a bunch of ideas from Clash of Clans.  It is NOT Blitzkrieg 2 reskinned.  I'm concerned about long term playability and freshness of new maps, but it is not an issue at the moment and the devs are updating the game frequently.How does this compare to Company of Heroes?  In my mind, it doesn't compare.  COH1 or COH2 are true RTS style games where you gather resources and build armies, and attack and replenish losses until one player out attritions the other.   In this game, you have a squad of tanks and infantry.  You attack another player and you both have a static number of troops.  The other player has static defenses which are managed by the AI.  (You never actually duel a live human, only the defenses set up by that person before they logged off)For many, this lack of true multiplayer may be a turnoff.  I'm a self professed lover of single player games...it doesn't bother me at all.  This game is more of a puzzle than COH.  You have a limited number of troops and you are trying to outwit the defenses.I can see some folks truly disliking this game.  I hope I explained it well enough so you can determine it for yourself.  I did compare to two very popular games and apologize if you have never played Clash of Clans or Company of Heroes and were unable to garnish anything from this review.  Happy hunting.

 Blitzkrieg 3 - Review Story:Blitzkrieg 3 takes place in WWII Europe, where you control three forces through their battles:Germany conquering France, Russia conquering Germany and America fighting for Sicily.Gameplay:In singleplayer, the game is a typical RTS, you command units, that are either added to your forces by you freeing them, fullfilling objectives or just as reinforcements. You have no impact on the types of units that your army is made of, so you basically have to adapt to your army, and not the other way around.The three nations have the same units, maybe with minimal slight variations, but the overall gameplay is the same for all. And this is where strategy comes in:The game is basically beatable with very few, very basic strategies, once you learned an effective way to defend/attack you can always go back to that, sinceall nations play the same. Thus the singleplayer is nothing special. The multiplayer on the other hand features something very unusual for this genre: You are provided with a base, the size of which grows with your level,that you need to build up and defend with units and structures from other players. Upon an enemy attacking, your units are controlled by AI. You gain resourcesover time, that you can use to buy and upgrade units and structures. When attacking, you are matched against a random player of similar level and have to fight their setup. It is an interesting concept, very often seen in mobile games.Pros:+Nice graphics, creating a fitting atmosphere+Troops speak in their native languageNeutral:~The multiplayer gameplay is new for this genre, but often seen on mobile devices~Singleplayer offers nothing specialCons:-The singleplayer is very basic-All nations play the same-There is no straightup 1v1 battleConclusion:I don't think I can give this game just one score, so I went ahead to give it a singleplayer-rating and a multiplayer-rating:Singleplayer: 6.5/10Multiplayer: 8.5/10If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

								I was hesitant at first to review Blitzkrieg 3, due to its “mixed” reviews on Steam. But given that it’s still in development, I figured I’d give it a shot, and I’m glad I did.Blitzkrieg 3 is a fantastic strategy game, with features I haven’t seen elsewhere. The key thing to remember is that it’s not Company of Heroes. It isn’t about moving your troops cover-to-cover. It’s about blitzkrieg—lightning war. It’s Patton’s no “holding ground” strategy, and the strategy that allowed the then-evil Germans to steamroll half of Europe.It also doesn’t feel like a WWII game. You can play as Americans and still fight against Americans, and the same goes for the Soviets and Germans. It feels more like a post-apocalyptic war-game with WWII weapons, where you build your defenses and raid the camps of neighboring tribes.Now that we have that out of the way, let’s get to the point: these factors are what makes Blitzkrieg 3 fun. While one side needs to try and plow through the enemy, the other side needs to build a base to defend against the attack, and this means finding all kinds of creative ways to ambush them.The game starts with you at your base. You get a set number of fuel and supplies to spend on upgrading building and units, or on your defenses. The base building is a game in itself, because your base is technically a full map that other players can attack at any moment.Think of it like Home Alone, only with tanks and guns.Read my full review here: http://techzwn.com/2015/07/blitzkrieg-3-is-like-home-alone-with-tanks-and-its-awesome/

								Blitzkrieg feels like it is now a franchise which has lost its soul, the essence of what made it fun and unique. The first Blitzkrieg was and still is unique in how it handles strategy, it gave you huge amounts of detail and background information to every unit and plenty of information prior to each battle so that players could make informed and calculated choices when executing their strategies. the gameplay itself was almost Total War-esque in its execution, you start each real time battle with a limited pool of units and make use of their individual talents to overcome the enemy to secure victory, Infantry for Urban battles, neutralizing garrisons, scouting, and cannon fodder. Tanks were used to overwhelm infantry in open spaces, combat enemy armor, and execute rapid, aggressive advances. Artillery was the hard counter to everything in the game (except air units) but is practically useless without effective positioning, thorough recon, and a little luck and patience. Tanks and artillery both carried veterancy through missions so if you could keep your units alive for long enough you would start the game with a sizable advantage over your enemies units but if they died you had to start from scratch with a new unit. Air units were often the deciding factor in each battle but were almost useless if you hadn't neutralized the enemies anti-air and air force prior to their deployment.As you have read, each unit felt like it had a purpose and had to be used intelligently to attain the most beneficial outcome and make progress. Blitzkrieg 3 feels like it is trying to be something it is not, and by doing that is losing what made it so special in the first place. Blitzkrieg 3's revolves around the same stale selection of maps, a hard counter combat triangle making it so units lose their versatility, practicality, and individuality and also game mechanics and campaign missions that fall flat due to their shallowness, lack of meaningful engagement, and cookie-cutter nature, you feel more like you are grinding through a chore than actively participating in grand strategy. How would I improve Blitzkrieg 3? I would advise Nivals games designers to go back and play the original game so they can recapture it's essence and improve on its mechanics with more modern game design ideas, then play the mods for the game such as Achtung Panzer! so they could see how to improve mission structure and presentation to the player, then finally openly and actively engage their community since in this new games development environment having closed communication channels for your audience to engage you will only prevent you from seeing how passionate fans want to help make this game great and live up to the legacy of the existing franchise.I cannot recommend the game in its current state as it is not a Blitzkrieg game, it is currently a bland, generic, cookie cutter, attack / defence style strategy game which genuinely feels like it was built for a microtransaction style economy and still feels and plays that way.TL;DR This game mechanically needs to be Blitzkrieg 3 and not Clash of Clans. I love you Blitzkrieg but you need to go home, you are drunk.

								As an early access game, Blitzkrieg 3 has a lot going for it.  However, early access also implies that you'll be receiving an incomplete or flawed experience from that of a retail (launch) game.  All of that said, I will try my best to provide an unbiased and objective review, detailing the qualities and deficits that Blitzkrieg 3 currently has.Pros:[+] Excellent graphics.  Beautiful, highly detailed maps--there are animals, roaming vehicles (trains, cars, etc.), and people who are doing daily tasks.  Trees fall down as tanks run into them, fortifications explode and crumble, and shots richochet off of vehicles creating an impressive realism.[+] Base building.  Organizing your upgrades is always fun.  There are tradeoffs to consider as you are leveling up, because you can't possibly level everything up at once.  Do you want improved infantry?  How so?  Do you work on individual upgrades to existing units, do you upgrade research options or upgrade the barracks itself?   The tradeoffs aslo exist in how you upgrade your defenses.  Do you want a widespread defensive network, or do you want a few key structures that are hihgly upgraded?  The options are impressive.[+] Strategy.  Despite what others are saying, there are lots of strategic options that open up conisderably the more you unlock and play.     -Command points can be spent on a variety of support options.     -Artillery to weaken defenses     -Smoke screen to hide advances     -Spies to scout the bases     -Reinforcements[+] Army composition.  The options are pretty limitless here.  There are four classifications of vehicles and five classifications of infantry, and determining how many of each can be a very important decision going into battle.Cons:[!] Pathfinding.  This is something that will presumably get better over time, but right now tank pathfinding is horrendous, at times.  This becomes even more apparent the larger the vehicle is.  And taking into account that as you upgrade your vehicles, you replace them with a larger chasis (stug to jadgpanther for instance), this makes it even more problematic.[!] No expanded multiplayer options.  Currently, there's only 1 v 1 asychronous battles.  I love the asynchronous battles, by the way, but I'd love to see 2 v 2 and greater options implemented.[!] Building off the above, there are no integrated community options.  No friends list, no chat system, no way to invite others to look at your base and basically zero player-to-player communication.  [This is a huge negative][!] A lack of unit explanations.  I would love to see a detailed tactical tutorial or in-game guide.  Right now I have no idea how to use an MG squad versus an assault squad versus a normal rifleman squad.  All three seem relatively "samey," and I don't have a clue what their operational differences are (if any) besides different stat adjustments.

While the people comparing this to offline defence mobile games are not wrong, I believe this kind of gameplay can be an engaging experience. I was confused. Still am, although after two hours I think I have most of the interface figured out.2) Bugs. Yes, the game is early access. But you knew that, it's an early access review. Regardless of the release state of the game, I am here to say that the current state of bugginess impacts the playabilty of the game. Objectives dissapear from your screen and there appears to be no way to get them back. Unit pathfinding struggles immensely. You cannot target units behind buildings (you will target the building itself). There appears to be no way to adjust a unit's heading when controlling it in battle, causing micromanagement dances when trying to get a tank to stop reversing into the enemy.3) The game seems to spazz out pretty horribly if you have a less-than-stellar internet connection. I have a less-than-stellar connection, but I am able to play other online games without major issue. This game freezes near-constantly, and for seconds at a time while playing. Worse, it does this WHEN TESTING AGAINST YOUR OWN BASE. Meaning, even what should be a local single-player experience appears to communicate through the game's servers.4) Attack/Defence balance does seem to be massively off, though others with more time in the game will have better opinions on this. Simply put, the defender and attacker appear to get the same number of units. As any RTS player will tell you, this is an automatic win for any semi-competent attacker. Concentrate on one point in the enemy's defences, and it's pretty much right-click to win. The attacker can even continue to call up reinforcements to replace any lost units.Until such time as all of these issues are resolved, I must strongly advise against purchasing this game.

								Early Access Constructive Criticism :D No Donkey sh1it!1.	To my pleasant surprise, the narrative in the tutorial mission alternated between Russian, German and American forces. I love the way the developers choose to give different perspectives during the same session. It’s an interesting way of displaying what kind of impact, your actions have on your foe, as the perspective changes. As you get the chance to play thru the eyes of your rival, you immediately see the aftereffect of your consequences. It’s a new take on storytelling, it’s very entertaining and refreshing. 2.	Cool moments: During a tutorial mission, you are given a few German infantry to clear out a poor Russian village. And here I was, in the middle of nowhere… hoping to spread democracy. Oh, well! We musn't disappoint our fuhrer, maybe we will find some MANA vodka.I split my infantry into two squads. I started off by sending squad one to occupy an empty house on the outskirts of the village. This immediately started a firelight, my first squad was taking incoming fire from a house further up the street. I tactically maneuvered my second squad thru a forest into an assaulting position on the flank. Using the new ability “assault building”, my second squad dashed forward out of the bushes into the house, screaming, pulling ears and vomiting on a chicken, ending up with five Russian KIA inside, oh and we found really fluffy teddy bear in the basement, to celebrate our victory, my heroic soldiers baptized it PUTIN. 3.	Sniper Unit - Sounds inaccurate in game. Last time I checked, yelling wasn’t part of the sniper weapons inventory. I swear to God, every time you give the sniper an order the dude goes ape sh1it, and starts screaming patriotic slogans.  The entire idea of having a dedicated unit going stealth, is silence. At least put some effort into making him act covert and whisper in response. Small changes to sound, can make a big difference to the atmosphere and characteristics of a unit. 4.	There seems to be no function at the moment to see your troops behind objects. And with such a rich and beautifully detailed environment, sometimes it’s hard to pinpoint your units in the field, you constantly need to reselect the units to find them.  Sorry, but I don’t want to spend my time searching for my troops on the battlefield. Especially when there is a mission timer involved.  Some sort of highlight is needed to distinguish your troops from the background, Men of war dose this brilliantly. Take note.5.	Ability “About face” - Being a Company of Heroes player for many years. I found myself selecting a vehicle and trying to drag the front armoured part towards the enemy. I’m abruptly, startled and confused when I realise that no such function is available in Blitzkrige 3. It’s 2015, happy new year! Ability’s like “About face” should be at my fingertips, and not hidden away in the far-flung-bottom right hand corner of the UI menu.Yes, yes, I know! There is a Hot Key, you can press “R”. But that’s so… 2005, I’m not stating that simplification is bad. But coming from a CoH frame of mind, my RTS behaviour is tuned to having fast and responsive controls. In the current state, I don’t feel that responsiveness is coming thru in Blitzkrige 3.I know there is a red compass-marker you can utilise to set your vehicles direction, but that option is way too sluggish and clumsy to use. Having an instant clock, with an arch of fire, popup underneath your vehicle is faster and better way to do it.Why not include a more fine-tuned approach of controlling your vehicles for those that want that possibility. Instead of this barebones, point and click. There is definitely room for improvements to be made regarding this issue.6.	At the current state Blitzkrige 3 does not offer any cover system for infantry. This is something that we should expect by today’s standards. There is a missed opportunity here in NOT letting the player use destructive environments as part of cover. A lot of effort has gone into creating a detailed destructive environment for Blitzkrige 3. And the developers have succeeded. I just wish the developers made the collateral damage more than just eye candy.  Let me illustrate an example.  - Battle for Monte Casino, On 15 February 1944 the abbey was almost completely destroyed in a series of heavy American-led air raids. The bombing was conducted because many reports from troops on the ground suggested that Germans were occupying the monastery, and it was considered a key observational post by all those who were fighting in the field. Only after the bombing were the ruins of the monastery occupied by German Fallschirmjäger (paratroopers), aiding them in their defence, because the ruins provided excellent defensive cover. The point I’m making, is that the destructive environment in Blitzkrige 3 could have been utilized to benefit both sides. This could have created some unique variation of strategies in battles. What you get instead is repetitive gameplay, with limited paths of approach.   7.	Which brings me to my next point, I find it odd that the developers of Blitzkrige 3 strongly incentivise the concept of artificial intelligence for defensive purposes, in base mode. Calling it “core component of the multiplayer experience.”Yet, the game is lacking any meaningful Ai behaviour, the way Ai responds to human players is with basic triggers, which activate on conditions. Example: A is true, there for activate B and repeat, basically. Someone once said, “The best defence is an offense!” So far, I haven’t found any way to change Ai behaviour perimeters when defending your base to aggressive stance or turtle defensive, hit and run or balanced tactics.It’s not fair to say that the Ai is inadequate. It dose its job, but it doesn’t like to deviate from a set path. Doing anything complicated like taking the initiative or making a surprise manoeuvre is out of the question. It’s all scripted and predictable behaviour, don’t expect to encounter General Rommel in the field, anytime soon.8. 								Many of the reviews I have seen have most of the same complaints that I have for the most part. Yes it is very pretty, everything looks fantastic, especially the buildings with the idle soldiers just about, but that is probably one of its strongest features is how pretty it is. Currently it feels lacking in content, and while it can be said that this is an early access game, so are other titles with more content and that do not feel like a ww2 version of clash of clans. Now I have not tried out the historical battles yet, because the first one is just a wave defense and currently, I have zero desire to play a wave defense. There is no other way to see if there are any other battles because it just takes you straight into it. No single player besides that really. From what I have seen so far it doesnt look like there are any custom commanders to level up either. Nor any interactive campaign map on the multiplay side, just build a base and attack people, which just feels so uninspired that I honenestly thought that I would have to wait hours for my buildings to upgrade unless I bought a premium currency. There really is not much of a cover system, so if you were thinking of company of heroes where you can hide behind a wall and throw grenades over it not really going to happen. While it does feel like it plays like blitzkrieg 2, it plays like blitzkrige 2. The controls are very similar without much improvement, as many other criticized the fact that you cannot face tanks, and you cant. I actually had a panzer one driving backwards until it spotted an enemy then decided to turn around. Blitztkrieg one and two are fantastic games, but just little tweaks here and there to fix old controls and such would be fantastic. The graphics are all nice and good so they got that part down. Another thing is a lack of an ability to actually call in reinforcements which I guess is because of their strange multiplayer not a campagin campaign thing that they have going.  Multiplayer is not an instant make a game better solution, and when done improperly makes things worse. Seeing as I have had many reservations about early access, the reason why I bought this was actually for the blitzkrieg one and two anthologies that I got with it and decided to give this a try anyways. Overal, this game needs a lot more work. It is dreadfully lacking in content and the fact that It is missing so much customization and single player aspects is very worrysome. There is no way I could recommend this game. Even just as a first impression I cannot recommend it, because you could buy far better things worth your time and money. That being said, I really want this game to succeed. I really do, the market is so lacking in rts, that people are recommend turnbased games because there is not anything else out there that is decent beside company of heores, total war, and starcraft. Plus I love blitzkrieg, and the opportunity to see a new one would be amazing. Right now however, this is just a sad shell of something much better.

								Avoid this for now. This game is so bad right now after nearly a decade of writing perhaps 1 Steam review, I've found this so bad that it warrants a negative review.Major issues:♥♥♥♥♥♥ pathfindingBattles that take way too long and and are way too short (I will elaborate later)♥♥♥♥♥♥ difficulty curveSo the pathfinding. You have to manually, individually command units. If you do a big move order units get stuck, they get jammed and the best part is, if two units get stuck on each other they do damage! Brilliant game design choice there. It makes the most basic of features tiresome - moving your armies about. Units get vaporised in seconds if you're not careful. The "artillery" (Including planes, hence the quotation marks) is incredibly overuses by the AI and will wipe your entire army if you do not react in time. Currently I have no AA vehicles and I have no idea if they are even in the game. You have defensive AA but that's only for base defense. So it's a tiring slog through a basic mission, meaning the whole thing becomes an over-extended bore. You have to carefully, slowly poke forward and with the pathfinding being so bad even that can fail miserably to stop you getting hideously punished. So battles can and do end VERY quickly, often unfairly so. Now why do they take too long? If you manage to somehow best the above, you have to take down the HQ and their radar (it calls for ENDLESS reinforcements from the AI - seemingly) meaning the longer you take the MORE enemy units there are. What a catastrophically♥♥♥♥♥♥design flaw - punish people for moving too fast, punish people for moving too slow. So battles are both too slow and too fast. There's no happy medium and the game becomes a chore. Seriously, you can even check the ingame bars - it shows your unit score in blue. I start with nearly 600. They slowly die off, so does the enemies. Then BAM the enemy counter goes from 60 back to 600. Yet I have nothing now to counter?♥♥♥♥♥♥game design 101. So you think to rush the radar? Bad idea. The enemy reinforcements spawn in the HQ, it's cluttered so bad pathing becomes even more painful and the way LoS works means they will be able to snipe you from the Fog of War with impunity. Another exercise in frustration. So yeah.♥♥♥♥♥♥pathfinding,♥♥♥♥♥♥game design choices and a terribly balanced AI opponent have turned me so off this game it upsets me greatly. Avoid.

So far so fun for a early acces game. It sure is not Blitzkrieg at all anymore but it still makes for a decent and addicting game. Conquering the bases that other players created, each and everyone different from one another proved to be just as exciting as the constantly new possibilities in moba games. Lets see how long this game can hold me. For now, it gets a recommend, the price of 30€ isn't much and the content is there even if unfinished and a tad broken.I hope the publishers take care of the future development of this game, so I don't have to change my review into a negative one. Therefore for anyone reading this, this review should be taken with the fact in mind that this game is in alpha status and that I, as of writing this, really enjoyed the 8hours I've spent so far with this game but might change my mind in the next few months unless I see progress.My biggest issues with this game are the lack of actual RTS elements. While range indicators are involved the basic combat system breaks down to rock, paper, siscors. The strategic part of the game lacks depth and needs drastic improvement. The movement too, Infantry should have different movement speeds based on gear and vehicles especially, should be fixed.The motions feel too clunky and units don't behave realistically.I also want more control over my units. I want to tell my Infantry when to charge, get down or use items. The armies aren't that big that a little more mircomanagement would hurt.Further the graphics are 'okay' but the sound needs improvement. Not just the ambience but the weapon and gear sounds as well. For anyone whining about it not Blitzkrieg, youre right, get over it, its still a decent start and the brand 'blitzkrieg' doesn't belong to you. Thats life, thats gaming, accept it - Singleplayer is still similar to the old games so enjoy that. Otherwise I recommend you Men of War or the first CoH, but stay away from CoH2.I'll say it one last time, if you're not okay with playing unfinished games, don't buy this - yet. However if you have no problem with that and you enjoy ARCADE RTS you're good to buy this already.

								Well being a huge fan of rts I was excited to see the best world war II strategy game first hand. And it of course fell short of that statement. I still find men of war to rule the ww2 strategy title and this game isn't knocking it any time soon. The game has several elements I enjoy and around the same amount I hate. Starting on a positive note the game functions and works and the gameplay is pretty fast paced. at ten minute around quick wits and lighting strategy is required, so prepare your blitzkrieg tactics. there is an extensive upgrade tree it's almost redic how much you have to do to upgrade your base. Resources are so abundant and yet it can take awhile to accumulate  them, at first it world make sense to fight battles because they are pretty easy. I was stomping the crud out so many people. but later on is where the game picks up and you will find yourself struggling to complete the same task you found easy at first. That being said it's boasted a-sync multiplayer is fancy for clash of clans style. Which is a little sad, hopefully a full fledged pvp head to head battle mode will surface, but for now get ready for ai battles. I have to admit the appeal of the game comes in spurts, this is more of a time waster then a game you want to spend hours playing. and after around 50 battles it gets dry and you pick up on most of the tactics defenders will use. The problem is you will face battles you can't win due to the leveling system. Trying to rush to the next tier leaves you vulnerable to players who just have better stuff and I found that not upgrading my units was leading to my units not being able to fight what should have been a sure match from prior battles.  It's weird when you run into the same tank you killed a million times but this time it barely takes dmg and wrecks you. The rts mode is pretty good even if it is ai you get control where your defenses are, what they are ect. You can deploy defensive structures(barbed wire, mines, hedgehogs, bunkers, ect.) and then a battle group (infantry, tanks) buildings can be garrisoned and you can test your defenses to see what other players might do to you. you can also watch replays which is important if you don't want bleed resources like a stuck pig.  I enjoy the game and recommend it for those players looking to kill time and want to experience what it would be like if a mobile phone game sexed up sudden strike and produced a decent game.   However this is no company of heroes or even old blitzkrieg (which comes with it) so all is forgiven.

								I've only played a few missions thus far but my first impressions are generally positive. I've always enjoyed the Blitzkrieg games and was excited when I saw this one.  Gameplay is generally similar to the previous ones, but it has better graphics. It most assuredly needs a 'save' option, as it's annoying to have to quit mid-mission and then have to start the whole mission over again. I also miss the variable stance option for infantry where they automatically go prone when under fire. I'm not fond of the new system where auxilliaries (air and fire support) are on a separate tab rather than displayed on the same screen as one's troops, but I can learn to live with it if it doesn't change.  So far there's no means of selecting which reinforcements you recieve-don't know if that's because it's no longer there or I just haven't progressed far enough for it to be an option, but if it is gone, I'd like it back.  Overall, I'd say if you liked the previous games you'll probably like this one.Now back to conquering/liberating Europe . . .Okay, so a few more things that need to be added from BK2. Infantry need to be able to entrench as do vehicles, or at least enter pre-prepared trenches. One of the weaknesses of BK1 and BK2 was the vulnerability of infantry which was partially corrected by the ability to dig in when under fire. Right now they're completely exposed and die like flies. Likewise, it looks like the ability to summon reinforcements is not yet present and it needs to be. I have fought the Arras mission six or seven times now and I always end up trying (and failing) to take the bridge with one damaged tank and 3 badly wounded infantry because I lost the others trying to take on five or six Char B1, one of the most heavily armoured tanks at the beginning of the war with a hull mounted 75mm gun.  In its present state, I would consider the Arras mission virtually unwinnable unless you have LOTS of luck on your side.  Also captured weapons-mortars, anti-tank weapons, et hoc genus omne used to be movable either by infantry or by vehicle and they should be again. I would also like to see a separate and distinct German and a distinct Allies campaign.

								Why do I love this game?   Great graphics, everything is well detailed, you can zoom in to get close to the action.   Now this is just like when you were a kid with your toy soldiers, tanks and jeeps etc., but X100!   If you don't take the road when you move your troops to your desired point, they crash through fences, mow down trees, the damage is very detailed!   The battlefield's are about 1kmX1km, and you can pan around the landscape to plan your attack, but it will not show you where all the enemies are.   In the beginning (where I still am), the first level was fairly challenging, and I battled towards the goal as a crow flies. Yay, I won, but my battle report was poor and lower rewards etc.   Try the first round again to kill ALL enemies was a completely different story,  It just gets harder and harder the more you try to fully complete a round.    There are several seperate battles on the map.  Inbetween some of these battles, you receive exp. points that you can spend immediately on reserve troops and tanks etc. and bring them into the battle. How cool is that?   There is a 'watch replay' button, but I haven't used it yet. Sweet!   Very intricate, detailed, in-depth, the sound is great, damage is great and stays that way.   Would you like to hunker in a bunker? Your soldiers can build a trench anywhere you like, and you can also build up defences around tanks in areas you want to defend.   Game is FUN to play!Update after 50 hrs: Before going into battle, there is so much military to choose from.                              In battle you use your selected units for certain situations, don't send your machine gunners to a gun turret!                              From the detailed characteristics of soldiers, to the dust on the road...                              Incredible game, just incredible.                              Super replayable, even if I'm victorious I may replay the same battle and try it completely different.                              I hate to cut this so short, but I would like to play this game now. Cheers!

								Being a sucker for WW2 strategy games and a old fan of the previous Blitzkrieg games I had to give this a try.I can see potential in this game but they need to do plenty of work in doing it to the Blitzkrieg we fans know and love. It is sad to see resupply removed and static heavy weapons such as artillery, something that was vital for the survivability of your more important assets in the older games was to relocate them. It is early access and I hope they will implement these functions at a later stage. I am also sad to see the reinforcement counter have been removed, instead you get points by taking objectives to call in reinforcements with. I especially liked BK2's as it forced you to go through missions with the minimal ammount of reinforcement called in so you had the most at the end mission, making you plan and strategize even on a front scale.There are a few bugs haunting this game too, the one that affects my gameplay the most is the one where infantry jumps out of trenches (they have been told to hold positon) and get slaughtered immediately. The constant online feature is a worrying addition to this game, and the constant global chat window is a nuisance and pops up as soon you press space (not to mention it is in the way at times even minimized).What I like is that infantry have a bigger role in this game, acting as scouts as your tanks have a very limited view range and add somewhat of a challenge. Sadly once I figured out that making small move orders at a time I can snipe out enemies without them even doing a thing took away that challenge.In all I can't recommend this game as for now, there are sadly better games out there if this is what we will get not to mention the older Blitzkrieg games which thankfully are available on steam too.Any newcomer to this genre, stick to the older series. 								Needs more work.I was a big fan of Blitzkrieg 2 when it came out in the mid 2000's. So far, this game was a bit of a dissapointment for me.  Issues- Not enough people playing online. I waited a very long time during multiple timeslots throughout the day adn wasn't able to get a match. I think the matchmaking system is based on your single player progress since I wasn't able to access the "tier 3" technology and wasn't able to match with people who had that tier unlocked.- Singleplayer is incredibly difficult. The singleplayer relies on you using your own units. This is problematic since you don't start out with many types of units and there is a cap on what you can use. I discovered the multiplayer button (titled "Frontline") on the main map by accident. It didn't give any indication of what this button did until I clicked on it. The units in the game pop up icons when something happens to them but there is no way to decipher these icons. - Blitzkrieg 2 had a nice unit stats window that would appear on the main UI when you clicked the unit. This showed the gun's penetration capabilities, the armor, the HP, and how much damage the gun can do. This one just tells you the armor on the vehicle: it's less intuitive than B2's. - Performance is subpar considering the graphics quality and the fact that this is a RTS. I encountered lag quite frequently during the singleplayer despite having a GTX 970 and an I5. I think the "clash of clans" style base assault multiplayer has potential. Early Access Review
								A relatively historically accurate RTS in the vein of Company of Heroes or Men of War, at least to the degree that any top down RTS could be historically accurate. As in Company of Heroes tanks do not destroy each other with one penetrating hit, infantry are not immediately gunned down in swathes by machine gun nests and so on, but that is unavoidable in order to keep the game playable from an isometric perspective.As in Company of Heroes there is a singleplayer campaign with historical missions as well as a traditional skirmish PVP mode.The main difference from the competition, and to me the most interesting part of the game, is the Clash of Clans style base defence/offence mechanic. You establish a base on a front line and set up defences where the terrain favours them: minefields and tank traps on bridges, bunkers and tank destroyers hidden in forests, etc. Then other players attempt to attack your fortifications with assault forces that they put together. If you are online you command your defensive forces yourself, and can call in reserves and various other support such as artillery barrages, dive bomber strikes, strategic carpet bombing, etc. If you are offline the enemy player faces your defenses controlled by AI. Surprisingly the AI actually defeats enemy players attacking you from time to time.As in any Early access game there seem to be a few balance issues, but on the whole the game seems quite polished at this point. I'm rather impressed with it so far and definitely prefer it to Company of Heroes 2. It's refreshing to be able to spend 100% of your time commanding units and microing, whether defending your own base or attacking an enemy base, as opposed to spending it on base building and build orders as in more traditional RTS.

Product received for free
Early Access Review
								DISCLAIMER: I was given a free key by the publishers to review this product. I received no other compensation or monetary gifts. I was not biased or swayed by anything the developers or publishers did or did not do for me.This review is NOT finished. This is an inprogress review as I work my way through the game.My final suggestions may differ from what you now read based on how well the game does or does not develop from this point. When the review is "final" I will make it public to all and this 'warning' will be removed.Through Early Access and funding by gamers who weren't too tight with their wallets, Blitzkrieg III was announced initially as a free-2-play multiplayer only game with optional purchase for a single player campaign and showed up on Steam's Early Access (EA) program shortly after.Every since it's EA announcement, I have followed the development of Blitzkrieg III with a bit of hope that they would take the new features of a modern RTS games and mix it with the power of today's graphic engines to make a Blitzkrieg III to make the past entries look ancient.And, I will admit, I was nostalgic for a title from my past returning to glory.However, nostalgia has a bad habit of making you remembering the past through rose-colored glasses and let's you think good things were REALLY good and the bad things weren't so bad.I had forgotten how advanced RTS's are today compared to ten years ago. I forgot just how valuable it is to use features a lot of people today take for granted.So after getting a press copy of Blitzkrieg III from the publishers, I was excited to relive the glory days of fight for Hill 772 while being outnumbered by the bad guys 4 to 1.I had assumed, that because so much time had passed since Blitzkrieg II and III, that III would be a totally different beast.Rose Colored Glasses Indeed.After firing up Blitzkrieg III the first thing you are greeted with a very simple choice;Choose Germany, Russia or the U.S. forces as your side.No idea of what type of units you'll have, starting population of your units, what the situation is... just dumped unceremoniously into an active mission.While I appreciate the tutorial starting from the beginning, I would have liked to have a main menu screen first to set my options!I find it extremely irritating when a game just auto-picks my screen resolution and blindly throws me into gameplay without letting me set these features first.On a console I can understand it, as you don't really have any options to worry about, but on a modern PC, 9 times out of 10 a game does not pick the settings I want to run my games with.I have an amazingly fast machine, but just about every game auto-picks medium of the road setttings. It is very annoying to have to play through a complete mission before you can shut that darn music down or go past 720p resolution.(I did find out later that I could go to the options screen at any time, but I usually am afraid to escape from a tutorial mission on a new game I know nothing about as I have had games that cleared your mission and some tutorials are hard to reset incase it makes you miss something) Devs, don't do this! Please, give us a Main Menu screen as our first choice in all games.My next problem is the starting mission. My first time I picked US forces. I am not told how to select or move anyone. I just have some guy telling me over voice to stop these German guys who are attacking my guys. Being that I have played RTS's, I have no problems figuring out the basics and get all my ducks in a row. But, if I had been new to the genre I would have been completely lost.I soon discover that this Blitzkrieg feels pretty simple. Too simple.My soldiers have no formation controls, other than crawl or run. Shoot or not shoot. Take over a building or exit a building. That's about it.No patrol routes, no "defend this guy", no "ignore bad guys and run like hell to the objective".So after slogging through a simple get-together with my scattered forces this is where I run into my next problem. I am told that enemy Italian forces are coming at me with superior armor and to bug out. The problem, is it doesn't tell you where to go to "bug out".There are a few spots on the map where you can see there are enemies, which show up as red dots. To the north is a new big red icon so I assume that the armor is coming from the North and decide to head south to get away from it.  Suddenly, my guys just get blown to smithereens as if aliens throw down hellfire. I just got scripted-killed because I went the wrong way...That's not good.Next time around I learn that the big red icon was the direction I was intended to go towards.(Remember, red on the map is supposed to mean "bad guy here" but, for some reason, they assumed I would know that this time, that red icon was the way to safety)What really chapped my hide was that it seemed like if I didn't go North, that I would be scripted to lose no matter how well I fought. So, this being in "tutorial" land I decide, "Hey, maybe it's just to get you through the basics." So I let it slide... for now. However, at this point, the tutorial has not "taught" me anything, except that you can't trust the color red on the map to always mean "enemy".I go back to the main screen and see that I have a choice of Generals to use. For some reason the game decided I didn't need to know about that either and had automatically picked a General for me, never once telling me how to pick my own, what the benefits are over one or the other.In the next mission I get some off-screen arty (with a cool down period) and later I get a button that shows I could call for reinforcements.It's at this point I am more confused.Why? Well, I see tanks I can order, but no idea how to get the "points" needed to order them.It shows I have 5 points, but never has it explained how I got those 5 points or how to get more.I am down to my last 2 squads and have about 50 bad guys with about 4 tanks. I so need to order a tank or two, but the reinforcements button for them are grayed out and I assume because the cheapest item on the list is 30 points that I do not have enough resources to order more.I of course get slaughtered. 2 squads of infantry against at least 50 enemy infantry and about 20 armor/arty isn't going to happen in anything resembling reality.So, for now, I have turned the game off in disgust.What is the point of this forced tutorial mode if it is going to throw overwhelming odds at you, and at the same time tease that that are other features, like ordering reinforcements, but takes no time to tell you what you did or didn't do to earn more points.This was not a tutorial in any scope of the imagination.This was a "throw you into the lake and sink or swim".If did not teach me how to play the game, nor did it teach me about any extra features.The only thing it taught me was that the game likes to stack the deck with more than normal amount of enemies against a small squad.Should you buy this game?It depends. Are you a seasoned RTS vet?Do you already understand a lot of WW2 combat tactics?Do you know a lot of the historical aspects of WW2, what generaldid what, where?Are you okay with a game not telling you about features and letting you figure them all out on your own?Are you okay with a game not having a ton of graphical featuresand bells & whistles?If you answered yes to all of those and you want to support the genre, then sure, but that comes with a warning:I don't know how close the developers are from being finished, but if this is anywhere near close to done, then I fear this title will never live up to it's previous pedigree. With it's heavy focus on multiplayer, titles like this live or die on how well it's user base is active. If the "meat" of the game is in the online aspect, then I feel this game might flop if they don't beef-up a lot of glaring problems.

								A black sheep of Blitzkrieg franchise.    I was expecting Nival to produce a further evolution on the epic Blitzkrieg 2, which shouldn't be too difficult, but now it seems more like a degeneration than an evolution. Many features already present on Blitzkrieg 2 are missing in 3. You cannot rotate camera with your mouse, you cannot control midair aircrafts, you cannot replenish ammo and HP, and more intolerably, YOU CANNOT SAVE OR LOAD YOUR GAME, one wrong move and you have to start over from the very beginning, yes. Instead they added some useless features, such as "capture the house" key for the infantry, which I have absolutely no idea what meaning it has.    Speaking of campaign, it is UTTERLY USER UNFRIENDLY, partly due to the game mechanics. The walkthrough of a single mission is very long. It is especially frustrating when you cannot save your progress (imagine you just lost your only tank and you can not load game). Also, the campaign is unbelievably DIFFICULT, DULL and severly RUSSIAN BIASED. Russian infantry can wipe out German counterparts for breakfast without a scratch (in 1941!). BT-5 can one shot a B1 frontally whereas latter takes more than 3 minutes to do so. And you have no reserves while AIs do. I highly suspect whether gamemakers themselves can clear the campaign or not.   The multiplayer is dull as well. The player matching is long and not based on any parameter like skill, the map is way too small and predictable, the game mode is lacking (only defensive and offensive). I don't want to continue, you name it.    Overall, it's a very disappointing experience and I can tell the devs are not enthusiastic about this game for a single moment. Maybe they shouldn't make a sequel of Blitzkrieg 2 at all. A legend is better kept than ruined.

								A game that could have been so much better :(I look at the screenshot, look at the description and bam. I am on board to the history train! I remember those hours spent playing Blitzkrieg 1 and 2! Such great times spent in my childhood, discovering great strategy games (alongside with Cossacks back in those days).People... In the screenshot I see planes, epic battles, BADASSERY! GREATNESS! I was like WO WO WO!I launched the game, crashed a few times, had to redo the tutorials. (tutorials take long). Go online, I take a commander by mistake, I can't choose another one... Well... OK? Thank god it was the tank commander! Why? Because here is the ULTIMATE STRATEGY GUIDE FOR SKILLZ MLG PRO! You are ready?Have a lot of tanks.... Basically, you want scouts to see far away, you want medium tanks to be able to kill any poor AI enemy coming towards you or to handle an ambush from a player. Then you want a tank destroyer... which will be used as a giant sniper to ... destroy everything that is in sight of the scout! AND VOILA!Oh... I didn't say the best! You make your own base (seems fun uh? A permanent base! :D but no... here's why) but this is like a base you can't customize, you need to have your building in a big square, you can still put defenses (mines, stuff to make people not to cross a road or anti tank guns and pillbox) and you can put some of your units here and there.Problem? Everything cost ressource points (logic) but the only ways to get them is by : Attacking an enemy and not loosing OR wait and hope nobody attacked you when you were away from your computer!Let me explain, you attack and steal the ressources of people (they created a beautiful base but my team of "tank snipers" wipped out everything), GREAT! Now you are back at your base but someone attacked you, YOU LOOSE WHAT YOU JUST WON! I mean, it happened to me too many times, especially when I was about to click on something and I couldn't after because someone decided to attack me when I was attacking someone else and the AI taking care of my defense was dumb (it's an AI).You level up your base with the few ressources you can get, developing paranoia, you level up your troops and defenses, IT TAKES TIME! GRINDING, PARANOIA AND TIME! It remind me of an old game which was based on the same policy and if I knew, I WOULD HAVE NEVER BOUGHT IT!Nevertheless, I tried to love and cuddle that game, I really tried. It's blitzkrieg! But no... It's Casualkrieg, it's paranoia, waste of time, I find the animation of the units / modelization not so great (except... the tanks?). Worst... 35 euros... spent... on a game :( AND THERE IS SO MUCH MORE TO SAY! (The commanders abilities, Unit restriction, the OP army with way more levels than you who attack your base while you're away and... 10 other dude who attacks you after him and because of the AI you loose.)So much more to say.... I tried steam refund but for some reason, they are still thinking you need less than 2 hours to discover a game and decide if you really want to separate from it. I wish there was a demo. I wish I knew :(If I didn't have the game and if someone gave me back my 35 euros, I would buy Men of War or EVEN COH 2 which is with LOTS OF DLCs! (DLCs... the new plague)

								This game is disapointing.  I did spent quite some time playing this game hoping it will get better as I progress. I finally gave up after spending over 30 hours on it.  First of all, all three factrions have the same unit types.  Tanks and infantry units do look different among US, Russia and Germany, but those units are the same type of heavy tank, tank destroyer, assault infantry and regullar infantry, etc.  They just look different but are with the same functions.  The buildings, defense units and structures look the same among all three factions. Multiplayer is a waste of time.  The upgrading system and game progress take forever.  It takes around 600k - 800k supply to progress from a level 5 headquarter to a level 6 headquarter, and each battle won will give you only about 7k of supply.  You fight in the maps with defenses created by other players.  However, there are only a few player created defense maps (around 4-5 per level).  So you fight the same battle over and over.  Imagine fighting the exact same battle 20 times hoping to get enough supply to upgrade to the next level.    Another disappointment is that you will lose your supply to other player when your defense (controlled by AI) is breached while you are offline.   Lastly, this game is buggy.  For example, units don't respond to command, infantry won't be able to destroy road blocks as that's suppose to be one of their skill.  So it ended up my whole army got stucked and I won't be able to finish the battle.  However, I must say the graphics are nice and the sound effects are good.  But unfortunatly, the gameplay is boring with repeatable maps and opponents.  I would not recommend this game to anyone at this stage of the game development.  Save your money for something else.

								I'd never played the Blitzkrieg series, though I had heard and seen a lot about it, and upon seeing this I thought now was the time to jump on the bandwagon. First impressions were positive; a decent UI, easy controls and gorgeous graphics (for what it is anyway), after the 1st mission and the invasion of Poland began I barely advanced into the town and units started getting stuck on pieces of rubble, refusing to attack and generally poor performance. I just assumed this was single player bug and decided to jump onto the MP. This was where my opinion of the game plummeted like an asteroid dropping through the atmosphere. WHERE THE HELL WAS THE BRITISH ARMY?!?! Anyway, after going to get a drink and having calmed down a little I, somewhat begrudgingly, selected "the Allies" (Nival, hear me out for a moment; IT'S NOT THE ALLIES IF IT'S ONLY THE AMERICANS!!!) First look and clash of clans deja vu started flooding back and whereupon I read through the chat box, others were complaning about this that and the other. I went to have shufti and see what units there were, and lo and behold! ONE BRITISH UNIT! The Churchill. With a dirty great big star on it (Yes I know that's the sign of the Allied exp. force) I couldn't even be arsed to play a battle by this point. The negative waves were too much. So I've gone and applied for a refund. Needless to say, I think I'll leave this alone for a good long time.Update: Now "SLIGHTLY" Recommended So, I wrote that *cough* review, a fair old while ago now, and given the discount which has fluttered along, I thought that, because I'm naive, that'd give Blitzkrieg another bash. And my oh my how it has come along over the past 9 months. For starters, the gameplay has been smoothed out substantially. It's not perfect, by any means, but units no longer get stuck, campaigns have been added and tweaked and such until they're now in reasonably enjoyable state and just general adjustments here and there to make it playable. Now you might think I'm being a bit harsh, well to tell you the truth, I've been waiting for a WWII RTS game which has enough elements of realism (Tell me on what earth a 37mm can pen a Valentine from the front. I'd REALLY like to know), but retains a good arcade style to it that it can appeal to the mass audience, for YEARS. No don't say Company of Heroes 2, that game is all about humping the fuel point long enough and hard enough until you win through sheer numbers and unbalanced units. Sudden Strike 4 looks decent enough, but the lack of technical gameplay doesnt avail enough for me. Anyway, back to Blitzkrieg 3; The game STILL retains some rather intolerable, if your reasonably learned on WWII, aspects. Such as nations only being the US of A, The USSR and Germany (Tell me what is wrong with that list, I'll wait) and what appears to be the bread and butter of this game; Clash of Clans, Blitzkrieg edition. Ok, perhaps I'm reading this entire game wrong from the start, but it's just my view. And the ATROCIOUS voice "acting". But other than that, this game has done ok to pull itself out from the rubble of a Lancaster bombing I gave it last year, but as a nice little distraction until that perfect WWII RTS arrives *cough* Steel Division *cough*, this will tide you over nicely until then. (I cannot speak for the MP as my limited time of repurchasing it hasnt allowed me to play it yet)I would recommend getting it when on sale. Even for 22.99, it's still marginally unpolished state really marks it off for more of a 15 quid game.
